p:
Next, a common trend for the temporal evolution of the total number of cases is sought. The following expression is used to interpret the latter data [ 21]:
2
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ n = 2^{{{t \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {t \tau }} \right. \kern-0pt} \tau }}} \left[ {\frac{1}{{n_{o}^{\alpha } }} + \frac{1}{{n_{\infty }^{\alpha } }}\left( {2^{{{{\alpha t} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\alpha t} \tau }} \right. \kern-0pt} \tau }}} - 1} \right)} \right]^{{{{ - 1} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{ - 1} \alpha }} \right. \kern-0pt} \alpha }}} , $$\end{document}

\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ n_{o} $$\end{document}
n o
and
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ n_{\infty } $$\end{document}
n ∞
correspond to the total number of cases at the start and the end of epidemic, respectively (i.e., the boundaries),
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \tau $$\end{document}
τ
is similar to the duplication time, and
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \alpha $$\end{document}
α
is a parameter that controls the temporal variation of the data trend, strictly its deviation from an exponential growth which we find to occur early in each data set. A high value of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \alpha $$\end{document}
α
also corresponds to a fast transition from the f phase to the s phase and the p phase.
